turns.content: Hi Grandpa, it's me! Don't you recognize my voice? I'm calling from the IRS office here in Washington. We're trying to reach a Mr. Johnson regarding an urgent tax matter. Is that your name, Grandpa? Please tell me so we can resolve this quickly before something bad happens.

I-I don't think this is the right number thenMy name's Walter, not Johnson. And why would you call me grandpa? I hope there isn't a mistake here.
Wait, what does the IRS want with me? Did they send me any letter or email about this?
My wife might know more about these things than I do. Let me see if she can help figure out what's going on.
(Wife enters) Honey, someone is trying to reach us from the IRS but I don't understand anything they're saying.
Is everything okay darling? They said something about taxes?
Oh dear, should we put them on hold while I look up any recent communications with the government?
Hold on a moment please. We'll get back to you if there's really an issue here. Thank you for your patience.
(Wife speaking into phone) Sir, my husband doesn't recall receiving any IRS correspondence recently and neither does he remember us providing this number as a contact point. If this is about taxes, could you send us formal written communication first?
Alright then, we'll keep looking into it ourselves and follow up properly with the official channels. Thank you again for your understanding.
(To caller) Sorry to cut our conversation short but my wife insists on verifying if there's an actual need for discussion with someone from the IRS.
We appreciate your concern but will contact them directly through legitimate means like their website or a phone number listed in government materials. Goodbye and have a nice day!
